title: How to Grow Akebia Quinata

steps.headline: Choose a loamy soil with a high sand content.
steps.description: Loamy soils contain a balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay. The akebia quinata prefers a loamy soil that is closer to being sandy than clayey. Because loamy soils drain well, they are ideal for the akebia quinata to grow in.

steps.headline: Try a sandy soil if loamy soil is not available.
steps.description: Although the akebia prefers a loamy soil, it can grow in sandy soils as well. Like loamy soils, sandy soils drain well, making them suitable for an akebia quinata to grow in.

steps.headline: Test your soil's pH level.
steps.description: Collect 1 cup (240 ml) of soil. Separate the soil into 2 different cups with each containing ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of soil. Pour ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vinegar into one of the cups. If the soil fizzes, then you have alkaline soil. If not, then pour ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of water and ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of baking soda into the other cup. If the soil fizzes, then you have acidic soil. If no reaction occurs, then you have neutral soil. You can also purchase a pH kit from your local garden center or nursery.

steps.headline: Adjust your soil pH, if necessary.
steps.description: Akebias are hardy plants that can grow in acidic, neutral, or alkaline soils. If your soil is highly alkaline (8 or higher), you may wish to reduce the pH slightly by adding compost or an acidic mulch (such as pine needles). If your soil pH is very acidic (5 or lower), you can raise it by amending with sphagnum peat.

parts.name: Selecting the Right Time and Place for Planting

steps.headline: Plant seedlings in late spring to early summer.
steps.description: Although akebias grow up to be hardy plants, they are tender when they are young. Planting young akebias in early spring may expose them to late frosts that can damage them and prevent them from growing.

steps.headline: Avoid planting the akebia on an east-facing wall.
steps.description: Because the warm sun can shock the akebia quinata in the morning after a frost, it is better to plant your akebia quinata on a south or north-facing wall. A west-facing wall is also suitable, but south or north-facing walls are preferable.

steps.headline: Provide partial shade.
steps.description: While akebias can grow in full sun, they prefer partial shade. Plant them near trees or structures that will provide partial shade. Because akebias can overtake smaller shrubs and plants, avoid planting akebias too close to other plants.

steps.headline: Plant your akebias 1 foot (0.30 m) from a wall, fence, pergola or trellis.
steps.description: The akebia quinata is a climber, meaning it grows upward at a fast rate. Because they are climbers, they do well near fences, walls, and other structures that allow them to climb. Once your akebias can reach the support structure, spread out their stems and use garden twine to fasten them to the structure. This way they will be able to cling and grow onto the support structure.

steps.headline: Plant your akebias 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) from an arbor or trellis.
steps.description: Akebias also grow very well near arbors and trellises. Once the akebias can reach the arbor or trellis, spread their stems and use garden twine to fasten them to the arbor or trellis.

steps.headline: Grow 2 akebias instead of 1.
steps.description: Plant the akebias 15 to 20 feet (4.6 to 6.1 m) apart. While a single akebia can grow pretty well by itself, it will grow much faster if it is planted near another akebia. The akebias will cross-pollinate, fostering each other’s growth.

steps.headline: Use a rake to loosen up the top soil.
steps.description: Use the rake to pull out weeds and remove other plants as well. Pour compost or fertilizer into the loose soil. Use a shovel to mix the soil and fertilizer together. Dampen the soil with water.

steps.headline: Plant the akebia seeds 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) below the surface.
steps.description: Cover the seeds with soil. Water the soil again until soaked through, about 10 seconds.

steps.headline: Plant your akebias in flowering pots to start them indoors.
steps.description: Use 1 foot (0.30 m) tall flowering pots. Place the pots near a window that receives full to partial sun, or in a greenhouse. Once the akebias have sprouted 4 to 5 inches (10 to 13 cm) tall, transfer them to the ground

steps.headline: Water until you have soaked at least 8 inches (20 cm) of soil.
steps.description: Do this during the first growing season. This will help your akebia establish a deep root system, which is vital for survival. Make sure to water your akebia every day in the early morning or late afternoon.

steps.headline: Soak 5 inches (13 cm) of soil with water when the soil starts to dry out.
steps.description: Use this method after the first growing season. Water your akebias every day in the early morning or late afternoon. Watering in the early morning or late afternoon will prevent the sun from evaporating the water too quickly.

steps.headline: Place flat stones or newspaper on top of the soil around the akebia.
steps.description: Flat stones, newspaper, or trash bags will help the soil retain its moisture. Soil that is consistently moist is vital for your akebia's survival. Avoid using peat moss to keep the soil moist. When peat moss dries, it forms a mat that will soak up any remaining moisture in the soil.

steps.headline: Avoid worrying about pests.
steps.description: Because akebias are hardy plants (and sometimes considered pests themselves), they are typically disease and pest free. As long as you grow your akebias in well-drained, moist soil, they will be fine. For example, they are known for being immune to honey fungus.
